Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: Critical Evaluation of the Hydroxyl Radical (OH) Meinel Band Einstein A Coefficients
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Meinel band nightglow emission from the OH molecule has been used for decades to characterize mesospheric temperatures. Aeronomers currently rely on emission coefficients ("A coefficients") that the PIs argue are in need of revision. Temperatures recovered using the existing set of A coefficients differ by up to 15 K from actual temperatures computed from first principles. Large uncertainty in the mesospheric temperature can have detrimental effects on modeling chemistry, transport and circulation of the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT). The uncertainties also undermine efforts to monitor the long-term temperatures in the MLT.

This proposal addresses the OH temperature determination by 1) using intensity-calibrated nightglow data that has been collected simultaneously over a large spectral range from astronomical sky spectra; 2) making comparisons between such recently obtained OH Meinel band line intensities, and the most recent first principles calculations of the emission coefficients. This research will contribute to understanding fundamental physical quantum processes, atmospheric motions on small and large scales, and long-term temperature change in the lower thermosphere.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At night, the excited molecular species in the Earth's upper atmosphere radiate faint chemiluminescence called nightglow. Hydroxyl radical OH is the molecule responsible for most of that nocturnal emission in the near-infrared part of the electromagnetic spectrum. This radiation originates from the thin atmospheric region, with a width of about 8 km and a typical peak height of 87 km, and it contains a wealth of information about the chemical and dynamical state of the Earth's atmosphere. A meaningful study of the observed OH emission intensities requires accurate knowledge of its fundamental molecular properties. Among these properties, the Einstein A spontaneous emission coefficients (also known as A-factors) are the least certain. In this project, we tested two recently reported independent theoretical sets of Einstein A coefficients for OH against the OH spectra recorded by large astronomical spectrographs and in the laboratory to determine which set of Einstein A coefficients best describes the observed emissions. Working towards this goal, we first measured integrated intensities of a large number of individual lines corresponding to radiative quantum state transitions of the OH molecule in all available observational spectra. Each spectral line corresponds to light emitted when an OH molecule reduces its internal energy by emitting a photon and changing its rotational and vibrational quantum numbers. Next, from these line intensities and the corresponding A-factors in every set, we computed the number densities of emitting OH molecules. This allowed us to compare populations of OH in the same emitting state obtained from different spectral lines and determine which set of emission coefficients produces the most consistent results. Grouping these results by the change in the rotational quantum numbers allowed us to examine the ability of the Einstein A coefficients sets to describe the rotation of the OH molecule. Then, grouping these transitions by the change of the vibrational quantum numbers, we demonstrated how well different sets of A-factors describe the vibrational degree of freedom. Besides providing critical evaluation of the sets of emission coefficients, the analyses conducted in this project revealed inconsistencies and uncertainties in the available observational spectral data sets and highlighted the need in better observational and experimental spectroscopic data for the OH radical.
